title: Exercise E01
body:
Exercise 1: Defining Sustainability

We are interested to know what you might already know about “sustainability” and what your current
understanding of it is.

1. Record a short video (max. 60 seconds) in which you answer the following questions:

  • What do you understand under “sustainability”?
  • Does sustainability play a role in your personal life? If yes, please explain how.

2. Submit your result in a common video file format (e.g. mp4, avi, 3gp, mov, etc.). Please add your full name to the filename!

Note: If you are unable to record your answers in a video, instead write them down in a short essay
(max. 200 words) and submit it as a pdf file.

You can find the full task sheet here. (Link)

Link for Submission: https://sync.academiccloud.de/index.php/s/MW3wY8uOVJbTrei

title: Team
body:
This course is taught by Prof. Dr. Benjamin Leiding and M.A. Theresa Sommer from the Clausthal University of Technology.  They are both working at the Emerging Technologies for the Circular Economy (ETCE) Lab. 

Research focus of the ETCE Lab:
— Intersection of IT and sustainability
— Circular Economy
— Self-organized, decentralized and distributed systems
— Machine-to-Everything Economy (M2X Economy)
Other courses:
— Emerging Technologies for the Circular Economy
— IoT and Digitalization for Circular Economy 
— Requirements Engineering

If you want to find out more about our work, you can visit the ETCE website (Link) to find what we are currently working on, the openly accessible material for all of our courses and a list of theses and project topics.

Here are some additional ressources where you can find ut more about our research in action:
— ZDF documentary (German) – Link
— Klartext Preis 2020 (German) – Link

title: Course Content and Learning Goals
body:
In the "Limits to Growth – Sustainability and the Circular Economy" course, you will learn about:

  • Basics of climate change, environmental pollution, and dwindling non-renewable resources
  • Introduction to the circular economy, sustainability, and related concepts (biocapacity, etc.)
  • Sustainability goals
  • Feedback loops and tipping points
  • Implications of closed systems with a finite supply of resources
  • Technology-focused and technology-critical approaches towards sustainability
  • Circular Societies

By the end of the course, you will have achieved the following learning goals:

  • Understand the concept of a circular economy, sustainability, and related concepts (biocapacity, etc.).
  • Gain a basic understanding of causes, dimensions, and the characterisation of climate change, environmental pollution, and dwindling non-renewable resources.
  • Being able to make high-level, transdisciplinary assessments of decisions and measures in a social, economic, and political context.
  • The ability to critically assess upcoming technological solutions enabling/facilitating sustainability and the circular economy.

body:
You will be able to find all content on this website. We will upload live lectures and slides here and you will also find the asynchronous learning material here. Every week we will unlock the new learning material on this website. 

News and updates:

Everyone: Please join the public Matrix room by using the following link:

https://matrix.to/#/#public--LTG-Course-WS2324:matrix.org

title: Exercises and Final Exam
body:
• Individual work → no group submissions
  • Submission of each exercise is mandatory
  • You pass by submitting an exercise – even if it is an empty page
  • You will receive feedback on your submission
  • Exercise = learning feedback

All exercises should be submitted through the Academic Cloud under the following link: https://sync.academiccloud.de/index.php/s/MW3wY8uOVJbTrei

We do not accept email submissions, please use the file drop link to upload your submissions.

Important: Always include your full name, your student email address and your student ID, so that we can track your submission.

***

Prerequisite for admission to the final exam (all criteria have to be fulfilled):

  • Submit all exercises

Final exam:

  • No Specific date yet
  • Either written exam (120min) or oral examination (20-25min)
  • More Information in the first weeks of the semester

title: Literature
body:
This course is not based on a single book and you do not need to buy a book to pass the exam.

  • Donella H. Meadows, Jorgen Randers, and Dennis L. Meadows. The Limits to Growth (1972).
  • Donella H. Meadows, Jorgen Randers, and Dennis L. Meadows. Limits To Growth: The 30-Year Update (2004).
  • Baccini et al. Metabolism of the Anthroposphere: Analysis, Evaluation, Design (2012).
  • Walter R. Stahel. The Circular Economy: A User's Guide (2019).
  • XR. This is not a Drill (2019)
  • W. Brian Arthur. The Nature of Technology: What It Is and How it Evolves (2011).
  • David Wallace-Wells. The Uninhabitable Earth, Annotated Edition (2017).
  • James Lawrence Powell. The 2084 Report: An Oral History of the Great Warming (2020).
  • Rutger Bregman. Utopia for Realists (2017).
  • (German) Stefan Rahmstorf, Hans Joachim Schellnhuber. Der Klimawandel (2019).
  • David Archer, Stefan Rahmstorf. The Climate Crisis (2010).
  • Gabrielle Walker, David King. The Hot Topic: How to Tackle Global Warming and Still Keep the Lights on (2008).

title: What is a MOOC?
body:
Massive Open Online Course

  • Remote and (often) asynchronous online courses not just for students enrolled in a specific university, but ideally open for everybody
  • Usually consist of pre-recorded lectures, interactive content and online quizzes
  • Some of you might have visited MOOC on platforms such as edX, LinkedIn Learning, Coursera, Udacity, etc. before

We are currently developing a MOOC for the Limits to Growth Lecture. This semester will be the a test run for this asynchronous and digital learning content.

We are very happy about any feedback you can give us to improve the course further! Just write us an email: etce-ltg@tu-clausthal.de

title: General FAQ
body:
What are the requirements to attend this course?
There are no formal requirements to attend this course. We welcome everyone who is interested in learning more about climate change, sustainability and the circular economy to attend this course!

In what language will the course be taught?
English.

Can I participate in the course even though I am not a student?
Yes!

I am not studying at TU Clausthal. How do I register for the course?
All you have to do is to send us an email (including your name and student ID) at etce-ltg@tu-clausthal.de.

I am not studying at TU Clausthal. Will I receive credits for this course?
If you are from Göttingen University, then yes! You can receive 5/6 CP as key competencies (Schlüsselkompetenzen), which are mandatory in many study programs at Göttingen University. If you are from another university, please ask your examination office whether it is possible to receive credits from courses from another university.

Can I get a certificate of attendance for this course?
After completing this course, you will get a confirmation of course participation from us, including the module name, number of credits, and your grade.

Do I have to attend the course in person?
No, even though we are giving in-person lectures at the Goslar Gotec, we will simultaneously stream the lectures and Q&A sessions via BigBlueButton or publish specific content aimed at asynchronous learning. It is completely up to you, whether you want to join us in person or online.

Do I have to attend the Q&A session after the lecture?
No, the Q&A session is not mandatory, but we strongly encourage you to use this time to ask us questions and discuss these relevant topics together!

Where do I find all the course material?
You can find all the course material on Github (Link). All the slides, exercises and lecture recordings can be found there.

What do I have to do to receive my credits?
When you attend the lectures regularly, submit the weekly exercises and pass the final exam, you receive the course credits.

What types of assignments do you give?
Since climate change and living in a sustainable way are issues that involve us all, most of the exercises we are going to be practical assignments that are often closely related to your everyday life. They are not meant to take hours to complete, but rather to make you apply what you learn during the course to your life and challenge familiar ways of thinking.

Do I have to finish all the exercises to get credits for the course?
Yes, the submission of each exercise is mandatory for passing the course. But the exercises are not graded, and you pass simply by submitting an exercise, even if it is an empty page.

What is the exam going to be like?
We either offer an oral or a written exam, depending on how many students sign up for the course. 

Who should I contact if I have additional questions?
You can always send us an email at etce-ltg@tu-clausthal.de

title: Carbon Capture and Storage Part 1
instruction: Select the play button to start the video.

title: Decarbonisation
body:
Alternative energy sources, such as solar, wind, tidal or fusion power, play a pivotal role in decarbonisation efforts. Unlike traditional fossil fuels, renewable sources produce energy with significantly lower carbon emissions, contributing to a cleaner and more sustainable energy landscape. The importance of decarbonisation lies in mitigating climate change by reducing the release of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, ultimately curbing global warming and its adverse effects on the environment. 

The following video will give you an overview of some alternative energy sources.
instruction: Select the play button to start the video.

title: Technologies and What They (Can) Not Do
displayTitle: Technologies and What They (Can) Not Do
body:
During the initial lectures, we explored the current challenges, such as the urgent matters of climate change, environmental pollution and resource scarcity. We have emphasised potential sustainability challenges and the consequences of global warming and resource depletion. Additionally, we have looked at different forms of political, collective or individual action in a lecture focusing on the timeline of political action regarding climate change.

This lecture will examine the relationship between technology and sustainability, weighing how technological advancements can improve or worsen environmental challenges. In this short introductory video, you will get an overview of what different strategies can be used to combat climate change, and we will introduce the three use cases of sustainability-related technologies that we will look at in detail during this lecture.
instruction: Select the play button to start the video.

title: New Component Title
instruction: Select the icons to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the plus icon followed by the next arrow to find out more.

_items.title: Renewable Energy Technologies
_items.body:
Renewable Energy Technologies include for example:

  • Solar panels: Convert sunlight into electricity.
  • Wind turbines: Generate electricity from wind energy.
  • Hydroelectric power: Generate electricity from flowing water.
  • Geothermal systems: Use heat from the Earth's core to produce energy.

_items.title: Energy Storage Solutions
_items.body:
Energy Storage Solutions include for example:

    • Battery technology: Enables the storage of excess renewable energy for later use.
    • Pumped hydro storage: Stores energy by pumping water uphill and releasing it to generate electricity when needed.
    • Flywheel energy storage: Stores kinetic energy for rapid release.

_items.title: Sustainable Agriculture and Food Technologies
_items.body:
Sustainable Agriculture and Food Technologies include for example:

  • Precision agriculture: Uses data and technology to optimize farming practices.
  • Vertical farming: Grows crops indoors using less space and resources.
  • Lab-grown meat: Produces animal-based products without the need for traditional livestock farming.

_items.title: Water Technologies
_items.body:
Water Technologies include for example:

  • Water purification and desalination: Provide access to clean drinking water.
  • Water-saving technologies: Reduce water wastage in agriculture and households.

_items.title: Waste Management and Recycling
_items.body:
Waste Management and Recycling include for example:

  • Advanced recycling technologies: Improve the recycling process for various materials.
  • Waste-to-energy: Converts waste into energy through incineration or other methods.

_items.title: Sustainable Transportation
_items.body:
Sustainable Transportation includes:

  • Public transportation systems: Promote mass transit to reduce individual car usage.
  • Bike-sharing and electric scooters: Encourage eco-friendly urban mobility.

_items.title: Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS)
_items.body:
Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) is a:

  • Technology that captures and stores carbon emissions from industrial processes and power plants.

_items.title: Green Building and Construction Technologies
_items.body:
Green Building and Construction Technologies include for example:

  • Sustainable construction materials and practices.
  • Energy-efficient HVAC (heating, ventilation, and air conditioning) systems.

_items.title: Sustainable Supply Chain and Logistics
_items.body:
Sustainable Supply Chain and Logistics:

  • IoT (Internet of Things) sensors for supply chain optimization.
  • Eco-friendly packaging materials and practices.

_items.title: Environmental Monitoring and Data Analytics
_items.body:
The field of Environmental Monitoring and Data Analytics includes for example:

  • Remote sensing technologies for monitoring ecosystems and climate change.
  • Big data analytics for understanding and mitigating environmental challenges.

title: Technology Advancement as a Political Priority
displayTitle: Technology Advancement as a Political Priority
body:
In the legally binding treaty on climate change adopted by 196 parties at the UN Climate Change Conference in 2015, finance, technology, and capacity-building were highlighted as the most important areas where countries worldwide must cooperate and support each other to combat climate change.

Article 10 of the Paris Agreement focuses exclusively on technology advancement, transfer, and innovations. The treaty underscores "the importance of technology for the implementation of mitigation and adaptation actions" and the need to "strengthen cooperative action on technology development and transfer".

Even without specifics on which technologies or areas of application this policy paper aims to address, it underscores the crucial role of technological advances and the sharing of technological innovation for political actors. Simultaneously, the ambiguity of the statements and the absence of clarity on political priorities raise questions about which technologies deserve further advancement and attention. Technology advancement is costly—not just financially but also in terms of the resources used during development and production. The uncertainty regarding its field of application and efficacy poses a significant challenge.

Source: https://unfccc.int/sites/default/files/english_paris_agreement.pdf

title: Electrification
body:
Electrification is crucial for combatting climate change due to its potential to reduce greenhouse gas emissions across various sectors. We can significantly decrease the carbon footprint by shifting from fossil fuel-based energy sources to electricity, mainly when generated from renewable sources like solar, wind, and hydropower.

In the transportation sector, electrification of vehicles, such as electric cars and buses, reduces reliance on fossil fuels and lowers emissions. Similarly, electrifying industrial processes and buildings, coupled with using renewable energy, contributes to a more sustainable and low-carbon economy. The versatility and efficiency of electricity make it a key enabler for integrating renewable energy, enhancing energy efficiency, and fostering a cleaner, greener future as part of broader climate change mitigation strategies.
instruction: Select the play button to start the video.

title: Carbon Capture and Storage Part 2
instruction: Select the play button to start the video.

title: Resilient Food Production
body: The negative impacts of industrial farming, only heightened by global warming and pollution, have underscored the urgent need for sustainable alternatives. In this video, we will look at some resilient food production techniques. We will be centring our attention on indoor farming techniques, offering a perspective that embraces a food production approach that is both resilient and environmentally conscious.
instruction: Select the play button to start the video.

title: GHG Emissions by Sector
body: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/ghg-emissions-by-sector" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;"></iframe>

title: Global Greenhouse Gas Emissions, by Sector
displayTitle: Global Greenhouse Gas Emissions, by Sector
body:
So, what are the main sources of our greenhouse gas emissions on a global level? This interactive graphic illustrates the distribution of overall greenhouse gas emissions (the sum of all greenhouse gases measured in tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalents) across different sectors.

Notably, electricity and heat production emerge as the primary contributors to worldwide emissions, which is why it is an important sector to lower overall global GHG emissions. However, the emission landscape varies across regions. In the United States, for instance, transport plays a  more prominent role than the worldwide average. Meanwhile, in Brazil, the majority of emissions originate from agriculture and changes in land use.

In the following video, we will discuss the most important current technologies in the energy sector and technologies that might be less widespread as of now but could help in the mitigation efforts in the future. Before we take a closer look at those technologies, use the interactive graphic below to understand how the global GHG emissions by sector have changed over time and how they differ if you compare two or more countries with one another.

title: Question 1
body: Question 1: Which of the following countries produced the most GHG emissions in the sector "electricity and heat" compared to other sectors (in 2019)?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Australia
Thailand
Portugal
Chile
Ireland

title: New Component Title
body: Question 2: Compare the GHG emissions between low-income countries and high-income countries. Which of the following statements are true.
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: The high-income countries produce twelve times as many GHG emissions than the low income countries.
In low-income countries the sector "Electricity and Heat" is the main cause of GHG emissions.
Even though emissions in the sector "Electricity and Heat" are slowly decreasing in high-income countries they remain the larger contributor of GHG.

title: Alternative Sources of Energy
body:
What Electricity Sources Power the World?

As the previous data showed, electricity and heating are the largest contributer of GHG emissions by sector. If we take a closer look at the sources of electricity, it becomes clear why that is. Until 2022 gas and coal remain the prime sources for electricity and together make up for more than half of the global electricity production. 

During the course, we have discussed the negative environmental impacts of fossil fuels, including coal, oil, and natural gas, which contribute to various ecological problems and pose challenges to the health of the planet. The combustion of fossil fuels releases significant amounts of carbon dioxide (CO2) and other greenhouse gases into the atmosphere. These gases trap heat and contribute to the greenhouse effect, leading to global warming and climate change. This has far-reaching consequences, including rising sea levels, extreme weather events, disruptions to ecosystems, and threats to biodiversity.  Additionally, burning fossil fuels produces air pollutants such as sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, and particulate matter. These pollutants can have detrimental effects on air quality, human health, and ecosystems. 

Fossil fuels are finite resources, and their extraction contributes to resource depletion. This not only poses a threat to future energy security but also leads to ecological disruptions as ecosystems are disturbed in the process of extraction.

Source: Hannah Ritchie, Max Roser and Pablo Rosado (2022) - "Energy". Published online at OurWorldInData.org. Retrieved from: 'https://ourworldindata.org/energy'

title: Lecture Recording
body: Our planet faces an alarming convergence of environmental degradation, resource depletion, and escalating social and political tensions. In this session, we will unravel the intricate connections between these challenges, exploring how environmental pollution amplify social disparities and spark political instability.
instruction: Click to watch the lecture recording.

title: Slides
instruction: Click below to view the lecture slides.

title: Examples of Sustainable Everyday Practices
body: Sustainable everyday practices are the key to building a greener and more sustainable future. By adopting energy conservation methods, reducing (food) waste, preserving water, choosing eco-friendly transportation, and practicing ethical consumption, we can make a significant positive impact on the environment. These practices are not limited to a select few but can be adopted by individuals from all walks of life.

_items.body:
By minimizing energy consumption in private home and at the workplace, the overall impact on the planet can be reduced.

This can be archieved through simple actions such as turning off lights when not in use,  utilizing natural light and ventilation, opting for energy-efficient appliances, and insulating buildings for better energy retention.

Additionally, embracing renewable energy sources like solar power can further reduce our reliance on fossil fuels.

Sustainable practices involve making conscious choices about what we consume.  Supporting local and sustainable businesses, opting for organic and fair-trade products, and reducing meat consumption can significantly reduce the environmental impact of our dietary choices. 

Additionally, embracing a circular economy by repairing and repurposing items, instead of constantly buying new, helps to reduce resource extraction and waste generation.

Sustainable everyday practices extend to transportation choices. By reducing reliance on private vehicles and embracing eco-friendly alternatives, such as cycling, walking, carpooling, or using public transportation, we can minimize carbon emissions and alleviate traffic congestion.

Furthermore, the adoption of electric vehicles or hybrid cars promotes a cleaner and greener mode of transportation.

To preserve this vital resource, it is important to consume water consciously. Adopting measures like fixing leaky faucets and pipes, installing water-saving devices such as low-flow showerheads, and practicing responsible irrigation techniques in the gardens are all important building blocks for that.

Capturing rainwater for household use and landscaping can also contribute to water conservation efforts.

The concept of "reduce, reuse, and recycle" lies at the heart of sustainable consumption behaviour. By reducing overall consumption, reusing items, and recycling materials, we can significantly minimize waste generation and reduce the strain on landfills. This involves using reusable bags, bottles, and containers, composting organic waste, and opting for products with minimal packaging.

Additionally, proper waste segregation and responsible disposal are also crucial aspects of waste reduction.

title: Reasons for Incorporating Sustainable Practices into your Everyday Life
displayTitle: Reasons for Incorporating Sustainable Practices into your Everyday Life
body:
Acting sustainably in your everyday life is not only important for the health of our planet but also for your own well-being and the well-being of future generations. Here are some reasons why it is important to incorporate some of these practices into your everyday life:

  • Environmental Stewardship: By acting sustainably, you become an active participant in preserving and protecting the environment. Our planet is facing significant challenges such as climate change, deforestation, habitat destruction, and pollution. Embracing sustainable practices helps to mitigate these issues and ensures the preservation of biodiversity and natural resources.

  • Personal Health: Sustainable practices often promote a healthier lifestyle. For instance, opting for organic and locally sourced food reduces exposure to harmful chemicals and supports sustainable farming practices. Walking, biking, or using public transportation instead of relying solely on cars not only reduces air pollution but also promotes physical activity, leading to improved fitness and well-being.

  • Resource Conservation: Acting sustainably helps conserve valuable resources such as water, energy, and materials. By reducing consumption and implementing efficient practices, you contribute to the responsible management of resources. This not only helps to address resource scarcity but also reduces the strain on ecosystems and minimizes waste generation.

  • Future Generations: Sustainable practices are essential for the well-being of future generations. By acting sustainably today, you are helping to create a world where resources are preserved, ecosystems are thriving, and the quality of life is enhanced for generations to come. It is our responsibility to leave behind a planet that is habitable and sustainable for future inhabitants.

  • Global Impact: Your individual actions, when combined with the efforts of others, have the power to drive systemic change. By acting sustainably in your everyday life, you inspire and influence those around you. Your choices can spark conversations, raise awareness, and create a ripple effect of positive change in your community and beyond.

In conclusion, acting sustainably in your everyday life is crucial for the health of the planet, your own well-being, and the well-being of future generations. By embracing sustainable practices, you contribute to environmental stewardship, conserve resources, and make a positive impact on a global scale.

title: The Difference Between Individual and Corporate Sustainability
displayTitle: The Difference Between Individual and Corporate Sustainability
body: Corporate sustainable behavior and individual sustainable behavior differ in their scope, scale, and the level of impact they can have on sustainability efforts. Individual sustainable behavior focuses on personal choices and actions, while corporate sustainable behavior involves the efforts and responsibilities of organizations. While both are important, corporate actions have a larger scale, influence, and potential for systemic change. Individuals play a crucial role as advocates and consumers, driving demand for sustainability, and inspiring change in their personal spheres. Ultimately, a collective effort from both individuals and corporations is necessary to address the global sustainability challenges we face.
instruction: Select the headings to find out more.

_items.title: Scope and Scale
_items.body:
Individual sustainable behavior typically refers to the choices and actions taken by individuals in their personal lives. This may include practices such as energy conservation at home, waste reduction, responsible consumption, and eco-friendly transportation choices. Individual actions, although important, generally have a relatively smaller scale and impact compared to corporate actions.

On the other hand, corporate sustainable behavior encompasses the practices and actions adopted by organizations and businesses. This can include initiatives such as implementing energy-efficient technologies, reducing carbon emissions, adopting sustainable supply chain practices, investing in renewable energy, and implementing corporate social responsibility  programs. Corporate actions have a larger scope and scale, as they impact not only the organization itself but also its employees, suppliers, customers, and the wider community.

_items.title: Influence and Responsibility
_items.body:
Individuals have the power to influence sustainability through their choices and behaviors. By making conscious decisions in their personal lives, individuals can drive demand for sustainable products and services, support environmentally responsible businesses, and advocate for sustainable practices in their communities. While individuals have a responsibility to act sustainably, their influence is more indirect and limited to their personal sphere.

Corporations, on the other hand, have a greater influence and responsibility due to their significant economic and social impact. They have the ability to drive change at a larger scale by integrating sustainability into their core business practices. By implementing sustainable policies, investing in green technologies, and incorporating sustainable principles throughout their operations, corporations can make substantial contributions to addressing environmental and social challenges.

_items.title: Causing Systemic Change
_items.body:
Individual sustainable behavior is vital as it sets an example, creates awareness, and inspires others to adopt sustainable practices. However, individual actions alone may not be sufficient to drive systemic change and address complex sustainability issues. While individual efforts can collectively make a difference, systemic change often requires collaboration, policy changes, and industry-wide transformations.

Corporate sustainable behavior has the potential to drive systemic change as corporations can influence supply chains, production methods, and consumer behavior on a larger scale. When corporations commit to sustainability and prioritize it within their operations, it can lead to significant shifts in market trends, industry standards, and policy frameworks.

_items.title: Accountability and Reporting
_items.body:
Individuals typically have limited reporting and accountability requirements for their sustainable behavior. While personal sustainability efforts are valuable, they often rely on personal motivation and accountability.

In contrast, corporations are subject to increased scrutiny and accountability for their sustainable behavior. Many organizations now publish sustainability reports, adhere to sustainability frameworks such as the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) or the Sustainability Accounting Standards Board (SASB), and engage in third-party audits to ensure transparency and credibility in their sustainability efforts.

title: Global Food Insecurity and World Hunger
displayTitle: Global Food Insecurity and World Hunger
body:
Before we start to get into the issue of food waste, it might be interesting to take a step back and look at another issue that hightlights the scope and effects of wasting food even more: world hunger and food insecurity.  

Food insecurity and hunger remain pervasive global challenges that continue to afflict millions of individuals and communities worldwide. Despite remarkable advancements in agriculture and food production, a significant portion of the world's population continues to suffer from inadequate access to food. In 2022, a UN report on "The State of Food Security and Nutrition in the World" reported that in 2021 as many as 828 million people were affected by hunger, a rise of 46 million people from a year earlier and 150 million more than in 20191. The consequences of this ongoing crisis are far-reaching and extend beyond immediate health concerns. Hunger and malnutrition impair physical and cognitive development, compromise immune systems, hinder educational attainment, and perpetuate cycles of poverty and social inequality.

Food insecurity and hunger are influenced by a multitude of complex factors. Poverty, conflict, climate change, inadequate infrastructure, and unequal distribution of resources all contribute to the persistence of these challenges. In rural and marginalized communities, limited access to fertile land, clean water, and productive farming techniques further exacerbate the problem, making it difficult for individuals and families to meet their basic dietary needs.

Addressing food insecurity and hunger requires a comprehensive and multi-faceted approach. It involves not only increasing food production but also improving access to nutritious food, promoting sustainable agricultural practices, enhancing rural infrastructure, and fostering social safety nets. Even though efforts are underway to combat food insecurity and hunger globally. Initiatives such as the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals that we talked about before in this course aims to achieve "Zero Hunger" as one of the most important targets for a sustainable future2.

With this information in mind, it is crucial to discuss food waste alongside worldwide hunger and fodd insecurity  because it enables us to address the inefficiencies and inequities in our food systems. By reducing waste, optimizing resource utilization, and fostering responsible consumption, we can contribute to the eradication of hunger and malnutrition, while promoting sustainability and ensuring a more nourished world for all.

___________

1 FAO, IFAD, UNICEF, WFP and WHO. 2022. The State of Food Security and Nutrition in the World 2022. Repurposing food and agricultural policies to make healthy diets more affordable. Rome, FAO. https://www.fao.org/documents/card/en/c/cc0639en.

2 UN. The 17 Sustainable Development Goals. https://sdgs.un.org/goals.

Retail
Out-of-Home-Consumption

_feedback.correct: Correct! About 52% of food waste in Germany is being produced in private households.

title: Food Waste: The Problem
body: For this course segment, we have a special guest that will discuss the problem of food waste and possible solutions together with Benjamin.
instruction: Select the play button to start the video.

title: The Importance of Talking about Food Waste
displayTitle: The Importance of Talking about Food Waste
body: This first introductory video gave you an overview of what food waste is, what the scope of the problem is and what some of the causes of food waste, especially in the retail sector are. Before we move on to possible solutions to the food waste problems, here are several reasons why focusing on food waste is essential especially in the context of global hunger and malnutrition.
instruction: Select the headings to find out more.

_items.title: Addressing Inequitable Distribution
_items.body: Food waste highlights the unequal distribution of food worldwide. While some regions struggle with excessive waste, others suffer from inadequate access to nutritious food. By reducing waste and improving distribution systems, we can work towards a more equitable distribution of food resources and alleviate hunger in underserved communities.

_items.title: Increased Food Availability
_items.body: By minimizing food waste, we can increase the availability of food for vulnerable populations. Instead of discarding edible food, it can be redirected to those who are hungry, thereby alleviating immediate food shortages and reducing the burden of hunger and malnutrition.

_items.title: Resource Optimization
_items.body: Food waste represents a significant loss of valuable resources, including water, energy, and agricultural inputs. By reducing food waste, we can optimize resource utilization and ensure that the limited resources available are efficiently allocated to nourish those in need.

_items.title: Economic Efficiency
_items.body: Food waste has significant economic implications. It represents a loss of investment in production, processing, and transportation. By minimizing waste, economies can unlock substantial cost savings and redirect those resources towards improving food security and nutrition programs, thus addressing the root causes of hunger.

_items.title: Environmental Impact
_items.body: Food waste contributes to environmental degradation, including greenhouse gas emissions and resource depletion. By tackling food waste, we can mitigate the environmental consequences associated with food production, contributing to a more sustainable and resilient food system for future generations.

_items.title: Behavioral Change and Awareness
_items.body: Discussions around food waste foster greater awareness and encourage individuals, businesses, and policymakers to take action. Raising awareness about the issue helps to shift attitudes and behaviors towards responsible consumption and more sustainable practices, both at the individual and systemic levels.

title: Food Waste: Possible Solutions
instruction: Select the play button to start the video.

title: Foodsharing: How to get Started
body:
To sum it up, food sharing is a sustainable everyday practice that holds great potential for reducing food waste and fostering a more environmentally conscious society. In the video, we have introduced you to the concept of foodsharing and foodsharing.de as a plattform to share food with others and prevent food waste. 

If you are living in Clausthal-Zellerfeld, and want to be part of the local foodsharing network, you can get in touch with Annika and the rest of the community by writing to them here clausthal-zellerfeld(at)foodsharing.network. If you are living somewhere else in Germany, you can check out this list to find out whether your city has its own foodsharing community!

After the best before date listed on a product, the food will be safe to eat but may not be at its best.

title: Course Overview
body:
Course Title: The Limits to Growth – Sustainability and the Circular Economy

Credits: 5/6 ECTS

Course Content:

  • Introduction to the circular economy, sustainability, and related concepts (biocapacity, etc.)
  • Sustainability goals
  • Basics of climate change, environmental pollution, and dwindling non-renewable resources
  • Feedback loops and tipping points
  • Implications of closed systems with a finite supply of resources
  • The sub-processes and steps of a circular economy – including the era of R and the era of D
  • Approaches towards sustainability
  • The full module and course description can be found here.

Requirements:

  • No requirements. The course is available to all students, no matter the study program.

Registration:

  • DigiTec Students and students from the TU Clausthal can sign up via Stud.IP.
  • Everybody else can register by sending us an E-mail here.

Course Dates/Times/Locations:

  • Lecture:
    • Wednesday 1:15 pm to 2:45 pm (Berlin time) – 01.11.2023 to 14.02.2024
    • Location: Goslar Gotec (Am Stollen 19 C, 38640 Goslar, Germany) or via BigBlueButton (Link)
  • Exercise / Q&A:
    • Wednesday 3 pm to 4 pm (Berlin time) – 01.11.2023 to 14.02.2024
    • Location: Goslar Gotec (Am Stollen 19 C, 38640 Goslar, Germany) or via BigBlueButton (Link)

title: 3 Perspectives on CCS
body:
Political Actor (European Commission)

"While CO2 emissions from fuel combustion have been declining in Europe, industries like cement, iron and steel, aluminium, pulp and paper, and refineries have inherent CO2 emissions resulting from energy-intensive industry processes. Carbon capture, use and storage can provide a key contribution to tackling these sectors’ emissions. Furthermore, it can help removing carbon from the atmosphere through carbon removals such as bio-energy carbon capture and storage (BECCS) and direct air carbon capture and storage (DACCS) and be a platform for low-carbon hydrogen production. (...) 
The Commission’s strategic long-term vision depends in part on CO2 removal techniques based on CCS: either in combination with direct air capture (DACCS) or biomass (BECCS) to achieve climate neutrality. The target of climate neutrality has been written into law by the European Climate Law (Regulation (EU) 2021/1119), which requires that Union-wide greenhouse gas emissions (GHG) and removals are balanced within the Union at the latest by 2050 and that the Union shall aim to achieve negative emissions thereafter. Furthermore, several organisations and institutions such as the Intergovernmental Panel on ClimateChange (IPCC), International Energy Agency (IEA) and National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL) argue that without carbon removals it is difficult to keep the temperature levels indicated in the Paris agreement (explore the IPCC report)." 

Source: https://climate.ec.europa.eu/eu-action/carbon-capture-use-and-storage/overview_en#why-do-we-need-carbon-capture-use-and-storage

title: New Component Title
body:
The BUND is a Germen non-governmental organisation that is committed to the preservation of nature and the safeguarding of the environment. The abbrevation BUND translates to "German Federation for the Environment and Nature Conservation". They have about 660,000 members and are one of the largest environmental organisations in Germany.

Which of the following statements is true?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: The BUND believes that CCS would lead to a rapid transition in heavy industry towards sustainable practices and the development of eco-friendly products.
The BUND argues that CCS could lead to heavy industry maintaining its current climate-damaging production practices.
The BUND expresses concerns that CCS could create incalculable risks for ecosystems, health, and climate, lasting for generations.
As a non-governemental organisation the BUND can make political decisions in Germany.
The BUND has no financial interest in promoting CCS technologies.

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

The BUND does not believe that CCS would lead to a rapid transition towards sustainable practices. Instead, they express concerns that CCS might allow heavy industry to continue its climate-damaging practices. Additionally, they also have concerns about the potential risks of CCS on ecosystems, health, and climate over the long term. Even though it is not mentioned in the text, the BUND is unlikely to have any financial interests in promoting CCS technologies.

As an NGO (non-governmental organisation), the BUND can advocate for specific policies and influence decision-making, but it doesn't make political decisions.

_incorrect.final:
You did not select all the correct answers! Let's sum it up:

The BUND does not believe that CCS would lead to a rapid transition towards sustainable practices. Instead, they express concerns that CCS might allow heavy industry to continue its climate-damaging practices. Additionally, they also have concerns about the potential risks of CCS on ecosystems, health, and climate over the long term. Even though it is not mentioned in the text, the BUND is unlikely to have any financial interests in promoting CCS technologies.

As an NGO (non-governmental organisation), the BUND can advocate for specific policies and influence decision-making, but it doesn't make political decisions.

title: New Component Title
body: The European Commission is the executive branch of the European Union (EU) and is responsible for proposing legislation, implementing decisions, and managing the day-to-day affairs of the EU. It is one of the critical institutions in the EU's complex political system. The Commission plays a central role in shaping EU policies, ensuring the implementation of common policies, and representing the EU on the global stage.
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: The European Commission highlights the importance of carbon removal techniques, including CCS, to achieve climate neutrality by 2050 and meet the targets set in the European Climate Law.
The European Commission denies the importance of carbon removal techniques in achieving climate neutrality by 2050.
The European Commission states that industries like cement, iron and steel, etc., have inherent CO2 emissions from energy-intensive processes.
In their statement the European Commission quotes many scientific publications, giving their statement higher authority.
The text does not mention any disadvantages of CCS technologies or take a critical view on them.

_feedback.correct:
Correct! 

The text does not address the disadvantages of CCS technologies or offer a critical viewpoint on them. At the same time, the European Commission references scientific publications to enhance the credibility of its statements. The Commission acknowledges inherent CO2 emissions from energy-intensive processes in the cement, iron, and steel industries. The European Commission does not deny the importance of carbon removal techniques; it underscores their significance in achieving climate neutrality by 2050.

_incorrect.final: You did not select all the correct answers! Let's sum it up: The text does not address the disadvantages of CCS technologies or offer a critical viewpoint on them. At the same time, the European Commission references scientific publications to enhance the credibility of its statements. The Commission acknowledges inherent CO2 emissions from energy-intensive processes in the cement, iron, and steel industries. The European Commission does not deny the importance of carbon removal techniques; it underscores their significance in achieving climate neutrality by 2050.

title: New Component Title
body: Saudi Aramco is a Saudi Arabian multinational petroleum and natural gas company, considered one of the largest energy companies globally. As a significant contributor to global carbon emissions, the company's role in the fossil fuel industry raises environmental alarms in the context of climate change and the global shift toward sustainable energy. Its state-owned status ties its operations closely to geopolitical considerations, potentially influencing regional stability and global energy markets. Questions about transparency and adherence to international corporate governance standards have been raised, given its state-owned nature.
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Saudi Aramco has expressed interest in and invested in carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies.
They have financial incentives to both further develop CCS technologies and to continue with producing fossil fuels.
For Saudi Aramco CCS is a way to move completely away from fossil fuels towards more sustainable, greener energy sources.
Their statement presents a very positive view on CCS technologies.
Going beyond CCS technologies, they mention the possibility of using the capture CO2 to turn them into marketable products.

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

Their statement reflects a notably optimistic stance on CCS technologies. Saudi Aramco has demonstrated interest in and financial investment in carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies. However, it's crucial to note that, for Saudi Aramco, the adoption of CCS signifies a partial departure from fossil fuels toward more sustainable energy alternatives. Instead, there is a dual financial motivation—driving the advancement of CCS technologies while concurrently maintaining fossil fuel production. In addition to CCS, they explore the potential of converting captured CO2 into marketable products, indicating a broader perspective on utilising captured emissions.

_incorrect.final:
You did not select all the correct answers! Let's sum it up:

Their statement reflects a notably optimistic stance on CCS technologies. Saudi Aramco has demonstrated interest in and financial investment in carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies. However, it's crucial to note that, for Saudi Aramco, the adoption of CCS signifies a partial departure from fossil fuels toward more sustainable energy alternatives. Instead, there is a dual financial motivation—driving the advancement of CCS technologies while concurrently maintaining fossil fuel production. In addition to CCS, they explore the potential of converting captured CO2 into marketable products, indicating a broader perspective on utilising captured emissions.

title: New Component Title
body: Question 3: Which of the following statements are true?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Mitigation involves efforts to reduce or prevent the emission of greenhouse gases (GHGs) into the atmosphere, thereby minimizing the extent of global warming and its associated impacts.
Renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar power, are considered harmful to mitigation efforts.

Mitigation efforts can include actions such as transitioning to renewable energy sources, improving energy efficiency, afforestation, and implementing policies to limit emissions from various sectors like transportation and industry.
Renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar power, are considered harmful to mitigation efforts.

title: New Component Title
body: Question 4: Which of the following statements are true?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Adaptation involves developing strategies to cope with and respond to the unavoidable impacts of climate change.
Adaptation focuses on increasing the vulnerability of communities to climate change by ignoring infrastructure improvements.

Adaptation strategies include e.g. developing early warning systems for extreme weather events, implementing sustainable agricultural practices, and creating plans for managing water resources in the face of changing precipitation patterns.
Encouraging deforestation is a key component of effective climate change adaptation efforts.
Adaptation recognizes that some level of climate change is already underway and focuses on minimizing its negative effects on ecosystems and human societies.

title: Environmental Impacts of Food and Agriculture
displayTitle: Environmental Impacts of Food and Agriculture
body:
Food and agriculture exert significant environmental impacts, contributing to deforestation, water depletion, pollution, greenhouse gas emissions, soil degradation, and biodiversity loss. Expanding agricultural activities often result in the clearance of natural habitats, leading to the decline of ecosystems. Water-intensive farming practices contribute to water scarcity, while livestock farming, in particular, generates substantial greenhouse gas emissions. Additionally, monoculture and the use of agrochemicals degrade soil quality, posing long-term threats to agricultural sustainability.

Addressing these environmental challenges is essential for fostering a more sustainable and resilient global food system.

title: Food Production and GHGs
body:
Food production is a major contributor to greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, stemming from various stages of the supply chain. Agricultural activities, such as livestock farming and rice cultivation, release methane, while the use of synthetic fertilizers and energy-intensive practices contributes to carbon dioxide emissions. Additionally, deforestation for agricultural expansion further exacerbates the carbon footprint. From cultivation and processing to transportation and waste, the entire food production system influences GHG levels.

Therefore, sustainable food production practices and reduced food waste, are crucial for mitigating the environmental impact of food production and addressing the challenges posed by climate change.

title: New Component Title
body: Question 1: Food production is responsible for approximately one-quarter (26%) of the world's greenhouse gas emissions.
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: True
False

title: New Component Title
body: Question 3: Which of the following statements is true?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Livestock, particularly cattle, produce methane, a potent greenhouse gas.
Food production is responsible for only 5 percent of the world's greenhouse gas emissions.
Land use, particularly for livestock, accounts for 24 percent of food emissions, involving the conversion of forests and grasslands into cropland or pasture.

title: 3 Perspectives on CCS
body:
Non-Governmental Organisation (BUND)

"For fossil corporations, entering a CCS economy would be very profitable. For ecosystems, health and climate, however, CCS would create incalculable risks that would span generations. Society would have to bear the consequential costs as a burden for eternity. CCS technology sets the completely wrong course. Heavy industry could continue as before instead of converting its climate-damaging production and developing sustainable products. CCS even creates additional emissions. The construction of new plants and pipelines for CCS creates long-term directional decisions that further justify and even increase the consumption of natural gas and oil. The expansion of renewable energies and an energy- and raw material-saving circular economy is thus slowed down."

Source: https://www.bund.net/klimawandel/ccs/ (translated from German)

title: 3 Perspectives on CCS
body:
Industry Actor (Saudi Aramco)

"We believe carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS) will play a role in global efforts to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, while ensuring the world can continue to thrive. 

How does CCUS work?

CCUS technologies capture CO2 emissions at source or directly from the air. CO2 emissions are then transported away and stored deep underground or turned into useful products. Capturing carbon has been used for decades to help improve the quality of natural gas, but pioneering new technologies may mean we can now potentially remove and sequester CO2 permanently. Moreover, we are exploring new ways to add value to waste CO2 by turning it into marketable industrial and commercial products."

Source: https://www.aramco.com/en/sustainability/climate-change/managing-our-footprint/carbon-capture-rbon-capture-use-and-storage

title: Conclusion
body:
So, after covering three different use cases, what can we say about the importance of sustainability-related technologies? What can they do, and what can they not do?

First of all, the role of technology in driving sustainable change is undeniable. Technologies, including alternative energy sources, carbon capture and storage (CCS), and resilient food production methods, are crucial in mitigating environmental challenges. However, it's essential to recognise that technology alone cannot be the sole sustainable strategy. While it is often vital, relying solely on technological solutions oversimplifies the complex issues. here are multiple dimensions to consider, including behavioural change on individual, industry, and political levels. Politicians may favour emphasising technology's role as it offers a seemingly straightforward solution, yet a comprehensive approach involves addressing behavioural changes.

This encompasses shifts towards reduced consumption, such as the development of circular societies, where the focus lies on prolonged resource reuse. Achieving true sustainability requires a holistic perspective that combines the benefits of technology with fundamental changes in behavior across various sectors.

title: Exercise E05
body:
Published on: 06.12.2022

Deadline: 13.12.2023 – 1:00 pm

Do you have any questions? Contact us via email etce-ltg@tu-clausthal.de or write a message in the Matrix channel!

Task(s):

What is the environmental Impact of your favourite food?

  • Pick your favourite fruit/vegetable that you regularly buy at the grocery store.
  • Compile a comprehensive list of all required resources that go into the production of this fruit/vegetable.
  • With the information you gathered, compute the environmental impact of the product system using LCA.
  • Your computation must at least consider the processes of production of the fruit/vegetable and the transportation of the fruit/vegetable from the “farm” to the grocery store (or where you bought it from).
  • You can use the automated tools provided by OpenLCA to do this easily.
  • OpenLCA Nexus has a collection of datasets, e.g., the Agribaylase dataset which contains existing LCA and LCI studies, which you can use to model your product system.
    • You can use the automated tools provided in OpenLCA to do this easily, using the free datasets provided on OpenLCA Nexus.
    • Suggested detailed tutorial: Link

 

Submission instructions

Submit the results as a PDF file. The PDF file should further contain your full name, your student email address and your student ID. Submissions in a wrong format or lacking that information will be ignored.

Submission filename: “E05-<firstname.lastname >.pdf”

  • Please upload your submission file under the following link:
    https://sync.academiccloud.de/index.php/s/2DowKa5TI0AYVBT

title: Exercise E04
body:
Published on: 29.11.2023

Deadline: 06.12.2023 – 1:00 pm

Do you have any questions? Contact us via email etce-ltg@tu-clausthal.de or write a message in the Matrix channel!

 

Task(s):

What are the three most impactful actions we could take to move the World3 model towards the SW run/results as discussed in the lecture?

  1.  Have a look at the 4 World3 scenarios that we discussed in the lecture (BAU, BAU2, CT, SW) → Note: Have a look at the links to World3 web version and play around with the model and learn about it in more detail.
  2.  What actions (which policies) could we (humans/politicians) act upon to move the simulation results of the World3 model towards the SW scenario.
  3.  Identify 3 proposals and describe each of them in 3 or more sentences.

 

Submission instructions

Submit the results as a PDF file. The PDF file should further contain your full name, your student email address and your student ID. Submissions in a wrong format or lacking that information will be ignored.

title: Exercise E06
body:
Published on: 13.12.2023

Deadline: 20.12.2023 – 1:00 pm

Task(s):

Suppose a new sustainability-related technology is presented to you. What are meaningful criteria to assess its contribution to a more sustainable world, i.e., how do you figure out whether it promotes greenwashing or not?

  • Collect at least 3 different criteria for assessing the technology.
  • Explain your choice.

Task(s):

Task 1: In the lecture, we presented a typology of the circular economy vs. circular society discourse (CE vs. CS – Typology). Which of the four categories (Reformist Circular Society, Transformational Circular Society, Techcentric Circular Economy, Fortress Circular Economy) do you prefer and/or deem to be more likely and why?

  • Explain your choice.

title: Exercise E03
body:
Published on: 22.11.2023

Deadline: 29.11.2023 – 1:00 pm

Do you have any questions? Contact us via email etce-ltg@tu-clausthal.de or write a message in the Matrix channel!

 

Task(s):

Political, Collective and Individual Action 

Addressing climate change requires collective efforts on individual, community, national, and global levels. In the lecture, we discussed the international and national perspectives. For the exercise, we want to look at what can be done on the community and individual levels.

  1. Work through the MOOC content for L04 (Link). There you will learn about sustainable everyday practices and the problem of food waste.
    1. Watch all the videos, read all the texts and answer the questions.
  2. In the lecture, we discussed the history of international and national actions. In part 1 of the exercise you have learned about individual actions and what a single person can do.
    1. In your opinion, what is more important when it comes to fighting climate change (and the other challenges we have discussed)? (1) Political Action (e.g. on the international or national level), (2) Collective Action (e.g. activism, protests) or (3) Individual Action (e.g. what you yourself can do).
    2. Explain your choice (minimum 300 words).

 

Submission instructions

Submit the results as a PDF file. The PDF file should further contain your full name, your student email address and your student ID. Submissions in a wrong format or lacking that information will be ignored.

Submission filename: “E03-<firstname.lastname >.pdf”

  • Please upload your submission file under the following link:
    https://sync.academiccloud.de/index.php/s/2DowKa5TI0AYVBT

title: Exercise E07
body:
Published on: 20.12.2023

Deadline: 10.01.2023 – 1:00 pm

Do you have any questions? Contact us via email etce-ltg@tu-clausthal.de or write a message in the Matrix channel!

 

Task(s):

Task 1: A Critical Assessment of the Circular Economy Model

  1. Review the lecture material (lecture slides and the videos). Pay special attention to critical principles, benefits, and goals highlighted in the lecture.
  2. Identify Shortcomings of the Circular Economy Model. Based on the lecture content, identify and list potential shortcomings or challenges associated with the Circular Economy model.
    • Refer to specific examples: Provide examples or case studies discussed in the lecture that illustrate the challenges and shortcomings of the CE model.
    • Explain each shortcoming in detail: For each identified shortcoming, elaborate on why it is considered a challenge. Reference relevant theories, models, or data from the lecture slides to support your explanations.
  3. Share your personal opinion of the Circular economy model. In your own words, what advantages and disadvantages does such a model provide? Also, reflect on the broader implications of a CE model for addressing the challenges discussed in the course.

 

Submission instructions

Submit the results as a PDF file. The PDF file should further contain your full name, your student email address and your student ID. Submissions in a wrong format or lacking that information will be ignored.

Submission filename: “E07-<firstname.lastname>.pdf”

  • Please upload your submission file under the following link: https://sync.academiccloud.de/index.php/s/2DowKa5TI0AYVBT
